muscle_facts.Right_branch_of_atrioventricular_bundle: Part of the heart's electrical conduction system that carries the impulse down the right side of the interventricular septum to the right ventricle.
muscle_facts.Septal_limb_of_supraventricular_crest: Part of a muscular ridge in the right ventricle that separates the inflow and outflow tracts.
muscle_facts.Anterior_wall_proper_of_right_atrium: The front wall of the right atrium, characterized by parallel muscular ridges called pectinate muscles.
muscle_facts.Posterior_papillary_muscle_of_right_vent: A muscle projection in the right ventricle that attaches to the chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve to prevent prolapse during contraction.
muscle_facts.Anterior_papillary_muscle_of_right_ventr: The largest papillary muscle in the right ventricle, it attaches to the anterior and posterior leaflets of the tricuspid valve, preventing backflow.
muscle_facts.Septal_papillary_muscle_of_right_ventric: A small muscle projection from the interventricular septum in the right ventricle that attaches to the tricuspid valve via chordae tendineae.
muscle_facts.Mural_limb_of_supraventricular_crest: Part of a muscular ridge in the right ventricle that separates the inflow tract from the outflow tract.
muscle_facts.Pectinate_muscle_of_right_auricle: Parallel muscular ridges found on the inner wall of the right auricle and atrium of the heart.
muscle_facts.Crista_terminalis: A smooth muscular ridge in the right atrium that separates the smooth posterior part from the rough anterior part containing the pectinate muscles.
muscle_facts.Superior_wall_of_left_atrium: The roof of the left atrium, where the pulmonary veins typically enter to deliver oxygenated blood from the lungs.
muscle_facts.Septal_wall_of_left_atrium: The muscular wall separating the left atrium from the right atrium, also known as the interatrial septum.
muscle_facts.Lateral_wall_of_left_atrium: The outer muscular wall of the left atrium, which receives oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins.
muscle_facts.Sinuatrial_node: Often called the heart's natural pacemaker, this cluster of specialized cells in the right atrium generates the electrical impulses that initiate each heartbeat.
muscle_facts.Right_thyro_arytenoid_proper: The main bulk of the thyroarytenoid muscle, it relaxes the vocal ligament to lower the voice's pitch.
muscle_facts.Left_thyro_arytenoid_proper: The main bulk of the thyroarytenoid muscle, it relaxes the vocal ligament to lower the voice's pitch.

muscle_facts.Right_vastus_medialis: The most medial of the quadriceps muscles, its lower fibers (the VMO) are crucial for stabilizing the patella (kneecap).
muscle_facts.Left_semimembranosus: A large hamstring muscle that extends the hip and flexes the knee.
muscle_facts.Right_semimembranosus: A large hamstring muscle that extends the hip and flexes the knee.
muscle_facts.Left_vastus_intermedius: Located deep to the rectus femoris, this quadriceps muscle is a powerful extensor of the knee.
muscle_facts.Right_vastus_intermedius: Located deep to the rectus femoris, this quadriceps muscle is a powerful extensor of the knee.
muscle_facts.Long_head_of_left_biceps_femoris: One of the three true hamstring muscles, it originates from the ischial tuberosity ('sit bone') and acts to extend the hip and flex the knee.
muscle_facts.Long_head_of_right_biceps_femoris: One of the three true hamstring muscles, it originates from the ischial tuberosity ('sit bone') and acts to extend the hip and flex the knee.
muscle_facts.Left_gracilis: The most superficial muscle of the medial thigh, it is a long, strap-like muscle that adducts the thigh and flexes the knee.
muscle_facts.Right_gracilis: The most superficial muscle of the medial thigh, it is a long, strap-like muscle that adducts the thigh and flexes the knee.
muscle_facts.Left_adductor_magnus: The largest and most powerful of the adductor group, it has two parts: an adductor part for pulling the thigh medially and a hamstring part for extending the hip.
muscle_facts.Right_adductor_magnus: The largest and most powerful of the adductor group, it has two parts: an adductor part for pulling the thigh medially and a hamstring part for extending the hip.
muscle_facts.Left_quadratus_femoris: A short, quadrilateral muscle in the deep gluteal region that is a powerful lateral rotator of the thigh.
muscle_facts.Right_quadratus_femoris: A short, quadrilateral muscle in the deep gluteal region that is a powerful lateral rotator of the thigh.
muscle_facts.Left_gluteus_medius: A key muscle on the outer surface of the hip that abducts the thigh and stabilizes the pelvis during walking.
muscle_facts.Right_gluteus_medius: A key muscle on the outer surface of the hip that abducts the thigh and stabilizes the pelvis during walking.
muscle_facts.Left_gluteus_maximus: The largest of the gluteal muscles and one of the strongest muscles in the body, it is the chief extensor of the thigh, used in climbing stairs and standing up.
muscle_facts.Right_gluteus_maximus: The largest of the gluteal muscles and one of the strongest muscles in the body, it is the chief extensor of the thigh, used in climbing stairs and standing up.
muscle_facts.Left_piriformis: A deep gluteal muscle that laterally rotates the thigh. The sciatic nerve often passes directly beneath or sometimes through this muscle.
muscle_facts.Right_piriformis: A deep gluteal muscle that laterally rotates the thigh. The sciatic nerve often passes directly beneath or sometimes through this muscle.
muscle_facts.Left_gluteus_minimus: The smallest of the three gluteal muscles, it lies deep to the gluteus medius and acts to abduct and medially rotate the thigh.
muscle_facts.Right_gluteus_minimus: The smallest of the three gluteal muscles, it lies deep to the gluteus medius and acts to abduct and medially rotate the thigh.
muscle_facts.Left_obturator_internus: A deep hip muscle that exits the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen to laterally rotate the thigh.
muscle_facts.Right_obturator_internus: A deep hip muscle that exits the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen to laterally rotate the thigh.
muscle_facts.Left_obturator_externus: A deep muscle of the hip that acts as a lateral rotator of the thigh.
muscle_facts.Right_obturator_externus: A deep muscle of the hip that acts as a lateral rotator of the thigh.
muscle_facts.Hamstring_segment_of_left_adductor_magnu: The lower, vertically-oriented part of the adductor magnus that acts like a hamstring muscle, extending the hip.
muscle_facts.Hamstring_segment_of_right_adductor_magn: The lower, vertically-oriented part of the adductor magnus that acts like a hamstring muscle, extending the hip.
muscle_facts.Left_adductor_longus: A long, fan-shaped muscle in the medial thigh that is a powerful adductor of the thigh.
muscle_facts.Right_adductor_longus: A long, fan-shaped muscle in the medial thigh that is a powerful adductor of the thigh.
muscle_facts.Left_adductor_brevis: A short adductor muscle that lies deep to the pectineus and adductor longus, assisting in pulling the thigh medially.
muscle_facts.Right_adductor_brevis: A short adductor muscle that lies deep to the pectineus and adductor longus, assisting in pulling the thigh medially.
muscle_facts.Left_pectineus: A flat, quadrangular muscle at the front of the hip that adducts and flexes the thigh.
muscle_facts.Right_pectineus: A flat, quadrangular muscle at the front of the hip that adducts and flexes the thigh.
muscle_facts.Short_head_of_left_biceps_femoris: One of two heads of a primary hamstring muscle; it originates from the femur and helps to flex the knee.
muscle_facts.Short_head_of_right_biceps_femoris: One of two heads of a primary hamstring muscle; it originates from the femur and helps to flex the knee.
muscle_facts.Left_tensor_fasciae_latae: A muscle on the outer aspect of the hip that works with the gluteus medius and minimus to abduct and medially rotate the femur.
muscle_facts.Right_tensor_fasciae_latae: A muscle on the outer aspect of the hip that works with the gluteus medius and minimus to abduct and medially rotate the femur.
muscle_facts.Left_semispinalis_capitis: A powerful extensor of the head, this is the muscle that often forms visible vertical bulges on the back of the neck.
muscle_facts.Right_semispinalis_capitis: A powerful extensor of the head, this is the muscle that often forms visible vertical bulges on the back of the neck.
muscle_facts.Cervical_part_of_left_multifidus_muscle: The upper portion of the multifidus, these deep muscles help to stabilize the joints within the cervical spine.
muscle_facts.Cervical_part_of_right_multifidus_muscle: The upper portion of the multifidus, these deep muscles help to stabilize the joints within the cervical spine.
muscle_facts.Left_platysma: A broad, thin sheet of muscle in the superficial fascia of the neck that tenses the skin and helps depress the lower jaw.
muscle_facts.Right_platysma: A broad, thin sheet of muscle in the superficial fascia of the neck that tenses the skin and helps depress the lower jaw.
muscle_facts.Left_sternocleidomastoid: A large, two-headed muscle on the side of the neck. Acting alone, it rotates the head to the opposite side; acting together, they flex the neck.
muscle_facts.Right_sternocleidomastoid: A large, two-headed muscle on the side of the neck. Acting alone, it rotates the head to the opposite side; acting together, they flex the neck.
muscle_facts.Left_semispinalis_cervicis: A deep neck muscle that extends the cervical spine and rotates it to the opposite side.
muscle_facts.Right_semispinalis_cervicis: A deep neck muscle that extends the cervical spine and rotates it to the opposite side.
muscle_facts.Left_splenius_cervicis: A neck muscle that works with splenius capitis to extend the head and neck.
muscle_facts.Right_splenius_cervicis: A neck muscle that works with splenius capitis to extend the head and neck.
muscle_facts.Left_splenius_capitis: A broad, strap-like muscle in the back of the neck that extends the head and rotates it to the same side.
muscle_facts.Right_splenius_capitis: A broad, strap-like muscle in the back of the neck that extends the head and rotates it to the same side.
muscle_facts.Left_iliocostalis_cervicis: The cervical (neck) part of the iliocostalis muscle group, which extends and laterally flexes the neck.
muscle_facts.Right_iliocostalis_cervicis: The cervical (neck) part of the iliocostalis muscle group, which extends and laterally flexes the neck.
muscle_facts.Left_longissimus_cervicis: The cervical (neck) part of the longissimus muscle group, which extends and laterally flexes the neck.
muscle_facts.Right_longissimus_cervicis: The cervical (neck) part of the longissimus muscle group, which extends and laterally flexes the neck.
muscle_facts.Left_levator_scapulae: A muscle at the side and back of the neck that elevates the scapula, as in shrugging.
muscle_facts.Right_levator_scapulae: A muscle at the side and back of the neck that elevates the scapula, as in shrugging.
muscle_facts.Left_scalenus_medius: The longest of the scalene muscles, it elevates the first rib and is a primary lateral flexor of the neck.
muscle_facts.Right_scalenus_medius: The longest of the scalene muscles, it elevates the first rib and is a primary lateral flexor of the neck.
muscle_facts.Left_scalenus_anterior: A deep neck muscle that elevates the first rib during inhalation and bends the neck to the side.
muscle_facts.Right_scalenus_anterior: A deep neck muscle that elevates the first rib during inhalation and bends the neck to the side.
muscle_facts.Oral_part_of_tongue: The anterior two-thirds of the tongue, which is the mobile part located within the oral cavity proper and is responsible for taste and articulation.
muscle_facts.Superficial_part_of_left_masseter: The larger portion of the masseter, one of the body's strongest muscles relative to its size, it powerfully elevates the jaw for chewing.
muscle_facts.Superficial_part_of_right_masseter: The larger portion of the masseter, one of the body's strongest muscles relative to its size, it powerfully elevates the jaw for chewing.
muscle_facts.Left_frontalis: The anterior belly of the occipitofrontalis muscle, it is responsible for raising the eyebrows and creating wrinkles on the forehead.
muscle_facts.Right_frontalis: The anterior belly of the occipitofrontalis muscle, it is responsible for raising the eyebrows and creating wrinkles on the forehead.
muscle_facts.Left_temporalis: A large, fan-shaped muscle on the side of the head that is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing), responsible for closing the jaw.
muscle_facts.Right_temporalis: A large, fan-shaped muscle on the side of the head that is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing), responsible for closing the jaw.
muscle_facts.Posterior_wall_of_left_atrium: The back wall of the left atrium, which is smooth and receives the four pulmonary veins.
muscle_facts.Apical_zone_of_heart: The lowest point of the heart, usually formed by the left ventricle. This is where the 'point of maximal impulse' can often be felt on the chest wall.
muscle_facts.Wall_of_inflow_part_of_right_ventricle: The lower portion of the right ventricle that receives deoxygenated blood from the right atrium and is characterized by rough, muscular ridges called trabeculae carneae.
muscle_facts.Lateral_wall_proper_of_right_atrium: The outer wall of the right atrium, which contains the openings for the superior and inferior vena cava.
muscle_facts.Wall_of_outflow_part_of_right_ventricle: The smooth-walled upper portion of the right ventricle (also called the conus arteriosus or infundibulum) that leads to the pulmonary artery.
muscle_facts.Wall_of_right_auricle_proper: The muscular wall of the right atrial appendage, a pouch-like extension of the right atrium.
muscle_facts.Wall_of_left_auricle: The muscular wall of the left atrial appendage, a small pouch that can be a source of blood clots in conditions like atrial fibrillation.
muscle_facts.Diaphragm: A large, dome-shaped muscle at the base of the lungs that is the primary muscle of respiration. Its contraction causes inhalation.
muscle_facts.Right_puborectalis: A U-shaped muscle sling that is part of the levator ani; its contraction creates the anorectal angle, which is crucial for maintaining fecal continence.
muscle_facts.Right_pubococcygeus: A key hammock-like muscle of the pelvic floor (part of levator ani) that supports pelvic organs and controls the flow of urine.
muscle_facts.Right_iliococcygeus: Part of the levator ani muscle group, it forms a sling that supports the pelvic viscera and helps control urination and defecation.
muscle_facts.Left_puborectalis: A U-shaped muscle sling that is part of the levator ani; its contraction creates the anorectal angle, which is crucial for maintaining fecal continence.
muscle_facts.Left_pubococcygeus: A key hammock-like muscle of the pelvic floor (part of levator ani) that supports pelvic organs and controls the flow of urine.
muscle_facts.Left_iliococcygeus: Part of the levator ani muscle group, it forms a sling that supports the pelvic viscera and helps control urination and defecation.
muscle_facts.Right_spinalis_thoracis: The most medial of the erector spinae muscle columns, it connects the spinous processes of the thoracic vertebrae and helps to extend the spine.
muscle_facts.Left_spinalis_thoracis: The most medial of the erector spinae muscle columns, it connects the spinous processes of the thoracic vertebrae and helps to extend the spine.
muscle_facts.Right_serratus_posterior_superior: A thin muscle in the upper back that originates from the upper spine and inserts on ribs 2-5, helping to elevate them during inhalation.
muscle_facts.Left_serratus_posterior_superior: A thin muscle in the upper back that originates from the upper spine and inserts on ribs 2-5, helping to elevate them during inhalation.
muscle_facts.Right_serratus_posterior_inferior: A thin muscle in the lower back that originates from the spine and inserts on the lower four ribs, helping to pull them down during forced expiration.
muscle_facts.Left_serratus_posterior_inferior: A thin muscle in the lower back that originates from the spine and inserts on the lower four ribs, helping to pull them down during forced expiration.
muscle_facts.Right_semispinalis_thoracis: A deep back muscle that spans four to six vertebral levels and helps to extend and rotate the thoracic spine.
muscle_facts.Left_semispinalis_thoracis: A deep back muscle that spans four to six vertebral levels and helps to extend and rotate the thoracic spine.
muscle_facts.Right_longissimus_thoracis: The largest of the erector spinae muscles, it runs along the thoracic spine and is a powerful extender of the back.
muscle_facts.Left_longissimus_thoracis: The largest of the erector spinae muscles, it runs along the thoracic spine and is a powerful extender of the back.
muscle_facts.Right_iliocostalis_thoracis: The thoracic part of the iliocostalis muscle group, it extends the thoracic spine and helps maintain erect posture.
muscle_facts.Left_iliocostalis_thoracis: The thoracic part of the iliocostalis muscle group, it extends the thoracic spine and helps maintain erect posture.
muscle_facts.Right_iliocostalis_lumborum: The lumbar part of the iliocostalis muscle group, it helps to extend and laterally flex the lower spine.
muscle_facts.Left_iliocostalis_lumborum: The lumbar part of the iliocostalis muscle group, it helps to extend and laterally flex the lower spine.
muscle_facts.Ulnar_head_of_right_flexor_carpi_ulnaris: One of two heads of this wrist muscle, it originates from the ulna and works to flex and adduct the wrist.
muscle_facts.Ulnar_head_of_left_flexor_carpi_ulnaris: One of two heads of this wrist muscle, it originates from the ulna and works to flex and adduct the wrist.
muscle_facts.Right_supinator: A deep muscle in the posterior forearm that wraps around the radius to supinate the forearm (turn the palm upward).
muscle_facts.Left_supinator: A deep muscle in the posterior forearm that wraps around the radius to supinate the forearm (turn the palm upward).
muscle_facts.Right_pronator_quadratus: A square-shaped muscle deep in the distal forearm that is the primary muscle responsible for pronating the forearm (turning the palm downward).
muscle_facts.Left_pronator_quadratus: A square-shaped muscle deep in the distal forearm that is the primary muscle responsible for pronating the forearm (turning the palm downward).
muscle_facts.Right_palmaris_longus: A slender, superficial wrist flexor. This muscle is absent in about 14% of the population and its absence does not affect grip strength.
muscle_facts.Left_palmaris_longus: A slender, superficial wrist flexor. This muscle is absent in about 14% of the population and its absence does not affect grip strength.
muscle_facts.Right_flexor_digitorum_profundus: The deepest muscle of the anterior forearm, it is the only muscle that can flex the outermost joint of the four fingers.
muscle_facts.Left_flexor_digitorum_profundus: The deepest muscle of the anterior forearm, it is the only muscle that can flex the outermost joint of the four fingers.
muscle_facts.Right_flexor_carpi_radialis: This superficial forearm muscle is responsible for flexing and abducting (radially deviating) the wrist.
muscle_facts.Left_flexor_carpi_radialis: This superficial forearm muscle is responsible for flexing and abducting (radially deviating) the wrist.
muscle_facts.Right_extensor_digitorum: Also known as the extensor digitorum communis, this forearm muscle extends the medial four fingers at their knuckle and wrist joints.
muscle_facts.Left_extensor_digitorum: Also known as the extensor digitorum communis, this forearm muscle extends the medial four fingers at their knuckle and wrist joints.
muscle_facts.Right_extensor_digiti_minimi: This slender muscle in the forearm is dedicated solely to extending the little finger.
muscle_facts.Left_extensor_digiti_minimi: This slender muscle in the forearm is dedicated solely to extending the little finger.
muscle_facts.Right_extensor_carpi_radialis_longus: A long forearm muscle that works with other extensors to extend and abduct (radially deviate) the wrist.
muscle_facts.Left_extensor_carpi_radialis_longus: A long forearm muscle that works with other extensors to extend and abduct (radially deviate) the wrist.
muscle_facts.Right_extensor_carpi_radialis_brevis: This forearm muscle is a primary extensor of the wrist and is often implicated in 'tennis elbow' (lateral epicondylitis).
muscle_facts.Left_extensor_carpi_radialis_brevis: This forearm muscle is a primary extensor of the wrist and is often implicated in 'tennis elbow' (lateral epicondylitis).
muscle_facts.Right_brachioradialis: A prominent forearm muscle that primarily flexes the elbow, especially in a neutral (thumb-up) forearm position.
muscle_facts.Left_brachioradialis: A prominent forearm muscle that primarily flexes the elbow, especially in a neutral (thumb-up) forearm position.
muscle_facts.Right_anconeus: A small, triangular muscle at the back of the elbow that assists the triceps in extending the forearm and stabilizes the elbow joint.
muscle_facts.Left_anconeus: A small, triangular muscle at the back of the elbow that assists the triceps in extending the forearm and stabilizes the elbow joint.
muscle_facts.Right_abductor_pollicis_longus: This muscle originates deep in the forearm and abducts the thumb at the wrist joint, moving it away from the hand in a forward direction.
muscle_facts.Left_abductor_pollicis_longus: This muscle originates deep in the forearm and abducts the thumb at the wrist joint, moving it away from the hand in a forward direction.
muscle_facts.Lateral_head_of_right_triceps_brachii: The strongest of the three heads of the triceps, it is located on the outer side of the humerus and is a powerful extensor of the elbow.
muscle_facts.Lateral_head_of_left_triceps_brachii: The strongest of the three heads of the triceps, it is located on the outer side of the humerus and is a powerful extensor of the elbow.
muscle_facts.Humeral_head_of_right_flexor_carpi_ulnar: One of two heads of this muscle, it originates from the humerus and works with the ulnar head to flex and adduct the wrist.
muscle_facts.Humeral_head_of_left_flexor_carpi_ulnari: One of two heads of this muscle, it originates from the humerus and works with the ulnar head to flex and adduct the wrist.
muscle_facts.Set_of_right_levatores_costarum_longi: These are the longer bundles of the levator costarum muscles, which skip a rib to insert on the second rib below their origin, aiding in rib elevation.
muscle_facts.Set_of_left_levatores_costarum_longi: These are the longer bundles of the levator costarum muscles, which skip a rib to insert on the second rib below their origin, aiding in rib elevation.
muscle_facts.Set_of_right_levatores_costarum_breves: These are the shorter bundles of the levator costarum muscles, inserting on the rib directly below their vertebral origin to help with inhalation.
muscle_facts.Set_of_left_levatores_costarum_breves: These are the shorter bundles of the levator costarum muscles, inserting on the rib directly below their vertebral origin to help with inhalation.
muscle_facts.Right_transversus_thoracis: A thin muscle on the inner surface of the front chest wall that helps to depress the ribs during forced expiration.
muscle_facts.Left_transversus_thoracis: A thin muscle on the inner surface of the front chest wall that helps to depress the ribs during forced expiration.
muscle_facts.Right_serratus_anterior: Nicknamed the 'boxer's muscle,' its primary action is to pull the scapula forward around the rib cage, as when throwing a punch.
muscle_facts.Left_serratus_anterior: Nicknamed the 'boxer's muscle,' its primary action is to pull the scapula forward around the rib cage, as when throwing a punch.
muscle_facts.Right_psoas_major: A powerful hip flexor that connects the lumbar spine to the femur. It is crucial for walking, running, and maintaining posture.
muscle_facts.Left_psoas_major: A powerful hip flexor that connects the lumbar spine to the femur. It is crucial for walking, running, and maintaining posture.
muscle_facts.Right_iliacus: This flat, triangular muscle lines the iliac fossa and joins with the psoas major to form the iliopsoas, the body's primary hip flexor.
muscle_facts.Left_iliacus: This flat, triangular muscle lines the iliac fossa and joins with the psoas major to form the iliopsoas, the body's primary hip flexor.
muscle_facts.Right_adductor_minimus: Considered the uppermost part of the adductor magnus, this small muscle assists in adducting (pulling inward) and flexing the thigh.
muscle_facts.Left_adductor_minimus: Considered the uppermost part of the adductor magnus, this small muscle assists in adducting (pulling inward) and flexing the thigh.
muscle_facts.Left_multifidus: A series of small, deep spinal muscles that span two to four vertebrae, providing stability and contributing to spine extension and rotation.
muscle_facts.Left_rectus_abdominis: Commonly known as the 'six-pack' muscle, it is a long, flat muscle that runs vertically along the front of the abdomen and is responsible for flexing the lumbar spine.
muscle_facts.Humeroulnar_head_of_left_flexor_digitoru: One of the two primary origins of this forearm muscle, which is responsible for flexing the middle phalanges of the four fingers.
muscle_facts.Left_internal_oblique: Located between the external oblique and transversus abdominis, its fibers run upward and forward, assisting in trunk rotation and flexion.
muscle_facts.Left_transversus_abdominis: The deepest of the abdominal muscles, its fibers run horizontally and it acts like a corset to compress abdominal contents and stabilize the core.
muscle_facts.Right_multifidus: A series of small, deep spinal muscles that span two to four vertebrae, providing stability and contributing to spine extension and rotation.
muscle_facts.Right_transversus_abdominis: The deepest of the abdominal muscles, its fibers run horizontally and it acts like a corset to compress abdominal contents and stabilize the core.
muscle_facts.Right_internal_oblique: Located between the external oblique and transversus abdominis, its fibers run upward and forward, assisting in trunk rotation and flexion.
muscle_facts.Humeroulnar_head_of_right_flexor_digitor: One of the two primary origins of this forearm muscle, which is responsible for flexing the middle phalanges of the four fingers.
muscle_facts.Right_rectus_abdominis: Commonly known as the 'six-pack' muscle, it is a long, flat muscle that runs vertically along the front of the abdomen and is responsible for flexing the lumbar spine.
muscle_facts.Septal_wall_of_left_ventricle: The muscular wall that separates the left ventricle from the right ventricle, also known as the interventricular septum. It is much thicker than the right ventricular wall.
muscle_facts.Innermost_intercostal_muscle: The deepest layer of the intercostal muscles, they assist in forced expiration by depressing the ribs.
muscle_facts.Internal_intercostal_muscle: Located between the ribs, these muscles run downward and backward and are primarily involved in forced expiration by pulling the ribs down.
muscle_facts.External_intercostal_muscle: These muscles run downward and forward between the ribs and are the primary muscles responsible for elevating the rib cage during quiet inhalation.
muscle_facts.Left_extensor_carpi_ulnaris: This muscle on the ulnar (little finger) side of the forearm is responsible for extending and adducting (deviating) the wrist.
muscle_facts.Right_extensor_carpi_ulnaris: This muscle on the ulnar (little finger) side of the forearm is responsible for extending and adducting (deviating) the wrist.
muscle_facts.Thoracic_rotator: A set of small, deep muscles in the thoracic spine that are key for producing rotation of one vertebra relative to another.
